response.answer_text: Louisiana is a very diverse state. We have a population of all nationalities, all religions. We are NOT uninformed, uneducated people. Our winters are usually mild with bouts of cold weather, it could be warm for weeks and then a cold snap will hit and it is cold. Summers are hot and humid. It is a humid state especially in southern part. Louisiana is steeped in traditions and the culture of long ago. There is always something to do and festivals galore. What part of the state you are thinking about moving to you will need to do some research as there is at least four different regions that may suit you. For example, living in the Northwest part of the state will give you a different experience than living in the Southeast part of the state. I will stop here as Mike Halphen gave all good reasons and I would just be repeating his answer. As to colleges… research is your friend. Here are the top 5. There are also 13 community and technical colleges, offering associate's degrees, technical diplomas and industry-based certificates. Founded in 1894 in the small town of Ruston, Louisiana Tech is an elite public research university that enrolls over 12,600 students from 47 states and 69 countries around the world. Students can pursue bachelor's degrees in the liberal arts, business, education, engineering, and the sciences; programs include: cyber engineering, exercise and health promotion, and molecular science and nanotechnology. There is also an interdisciplinary studies option that gives students at this Louisiana college an opportunity to create their own degree. Recognized as one of the best colleges in Louisiana, University of Louisiana at Lafayette is recognized as a premiere research university by the Carnegie Foundation, with SMART classrooms, cutting-edge facilities, and hands-on research experiences available to all undergraduate students. UL has over 80 bachelor's degree programs, including architectural studies, informatics, the visual arts, and a number of pre-professional degrees. Tulane University of Louisiana provides a uniquely flexible approach to helping students create degree programs that align specifically with their career objectives and intellectual interests; students choose double-major combinations from the university's 75 undergraduate offerings. The Creative Premedical Scholars Program is designed for students who want to major in the liberal arts but pursue a career in medicine, and a variety of other special programs cater to students who think outside the box. Students can also take advantage of more than 100 study abroad programs in over 40 countries, the most diverse set offered by Louisiana colleges. Tulane's shuttle system provides students with safe and reliable transportation between the university's campuses in New Orleans, as well as to popular sites throughout the city. Tulane embraces its diverse student population, with its most recent class hailing from 47 states and 21 countries. Based in Baton Rouge, Franciscan University is a Roman Catholic institution that ranks among the top healthcare schools in Louisiana. Founded in 1923 as a nursing school, the university offers degrees in arts and sciences, business, and health professions. Students can pursue associate, bachelor's, master's, and doctoral degrees in areas such as respiratory therapy, medical laboratory science, nutritional sciences, and nurse anesthesia. The university offers liberal arts minors to augment undergraduate healthcare majors, including minors in English, ethics, philosophy, and writing. Located on the Mississippi River and within walking distance of downtown New Orleans, the University of Holy Cross was founded as a Ministry of the Marianites Sisters of Holy Cross and continues to provide a faith-based education at the core of its programs. In the tradition of liberal arts studies, undergraduate degrees include programs in the allied health sciences, English, education, and theology. Students who are unsure of what path they want to follow may pursue a general studies degree that allows them to tailor their program to fit their interests.

I was born in Jackson, Mississippi, less than 200 miles north of New Orleans, LA. My family took vacations in New Orleans a few times every year and I decided at a very young age that I would move there as soon as I could. My parents would always stay in hotels within the French Quarters and when they would go to Pete Fountain’s and Al Hirt’s shows (considered adult entertainment), they’d drop me off at Preservation Hall Jazz club on Saint Peter Street. I would sit for hours on end at the feet of the world’s most famous Dixie-Land musicians, enjoying the music that helped make New Orleans a mecca for music. When I turned thirteen, the musicians would often send me across the street to a bar for adult beverages…no bartender would question me when I told them the drinks were for Sweet Emma’s band members. Not long after graduating from high school, I moved to New Orleans where I lived for thirty-three years. I met and married my wife there and we had a double-shotgun house (living on one side, renting out the other) near City Park. We moved away from New Orleans in 2009 and headed to Seattle, WA to be closer to her parents and relatives. I’m in a constant state of home-sickness, as nowhere else compares to the amazing history, culture, architecture, people and food.
